commit_message:
Update system hosts file to understand local domainnames

Currently Manila service image has no info about its local domainnames,
and recent Neutron feature [1] became incompatible with Manila because of it.
That led to b_u_g 1535692. Neutron started adding default DNS resolvers to
Nova VMs, and Manila was failing because of timeouts, since default resolvers
do not know this local machine domainnames. So, add static domainname info
to make new Neutron feature be able to work with Manila.

[1] I17a884f467d307432a06f67a9dd93ed2fa6081a3

Closes-Bug: #1535804
Change-Id: Icf7f189d621e9686c4bb449b5770b83e4bd072ee

commit_message:
Distributed periodic tasks spec

This spec describes the way to implement
distributed periodic tasks

Partially-implements bp: distributed-periodics

Change-Id: I3b8c6dfbe845c602a668f9dbd3c7357386eec483
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs refs/changes/69/272569/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Support of distributed periodic tasks ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/sahara/+spec/distributed-periodics This specification proposes to add distributed periodic tasks. Problem description =================== Currently periodic tasks are executed on each engine simultaneously, so that the amount of time between those tasks can be very small and load between engines is not balanced. Distribution of periodic tasks between engines can deal with both problems. Also currently we have 2 periodic tasks that make clusters cleanup. Clusters terminations in these tasks are performed in cycle with direct termination calls (bypassing OPS). This approach leads to cessation of periodic tasks on particular engine during cluster termination (it harms even more if some problems during termination occurs). Proposed change =============== This change consists of two things: * Will be added ability to terminate clusters in periodic tasks via OPS; * Will be added support of distributed periodic tasks. Distributed periodic tasks will be based on HashRing implementation and Tooz library that provides group membership support for a set of backends [1]. Backend will be configured with ``periodic_coordination_backend`` option. There will be only one group called ``sahara-periodic-tasks``. Once a group is created, any coordinator can join the group and become a member of it. As an engine joins the group and builds HashRing, hash of its ID is being made, and that hash determines the data it's going to be responsible for. Everything between this number and one that's next in the ring and that belongs to a different engine, is now belong to this engine. The only remaining problem is that some engines will have disproportionately large space before them, and this will result in greater load on them. This can be ameliorated by adding each server to the ring a number of times in different places. This is achieved by having a replica count (will be 100 by default). HashRing will be rebuilt before execution of each periodic task to reflect actual state of coordination group. ``sahara.service.coordinator.py`` module and two classes will be added: * ``Coordinator`` class will contain basic coordination and grouping methods: .. sourcecode:: python class Coordinator(object): def __init__(self, backend_url): ... def heartbeat(self): ... def join_group(self, group_id): ... def get_members(self, group_id): ... * ``HashRing`` class will contain methods for ring building and subset extraction: .. sourcecode:: python class HashRing(Coordinator): def __init__(self, backend_url, group_id, replicas=100): ... def _build_ring(self): ... def get_subset(self, objects): ... Now we have 4 periodic tasks. For each of them will be listed what exactly will be distributed: * ``update_job_statuses`` Each engine will get a list of all job executions but will update statuses for only a part of them according to a hash values of their IDs. * ``terminate_unneeded_transient_clusters`` Only one engine will get a list of all clusters that need to be terminated and will request their termination via OPS. * ``terminate_incomplete_clusters`` Same as for ``terminate_unneeded_transient_clusters``. * ``check_for_zombie_proxy_users`` Each engine will get a list of users but will check if it is zombie or not only for part of them. Also we will have a periodic task for health checks soon. Health check task will be executed on clusters and this clusters will be split among engines in the same way as job executions for ``update_job_statuses``. If a coordination backend is not provided during configuration, periodic tasks will be launched in an old-fashioned way and HashRing will not be built. The same situation occurs if a connection to the coordinator will be lost. But once connection is established again, periodic tasks will be executed in the distributed mode. In order to keep the connection to the coordination server active, ``heartbeat`` method will be called regularly (every ``heartbeat_timeout`` seconds) in a separate thread. Configurable number of threads (each thread will be a separate member of a group) performing periodic tasks will be launched. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- Coordination backend should be configured. Developer impact ---------------- None Sahara-image-elements impact ---------------------------- None Sahara-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: apavlov-n Work Items ---------- * Adding ability to terminate clusters in periodic tasks via OPS; * Implementing HashRing for distribution of periodic tasks; * Documenting changes in periodic tasks configuration. Dependencies ============ Tooz package [2] Testing ======= Unit tests, enabling distributed periodics in intergration tests with one of the supported backends (for example, ZooKeeper) and manual testing for all available backends [1] supported by Tooz library. Documentation Impact ==================== Sahara REST API documentation in api-ref will be updated. References ========== [1]: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tooz/compatibility.html#driver-support [2]: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tooz

commit_message:
Remove glance_store specific unit tests

TestStoreAddToBackend contains a set of tests that should belong to
the glance_store. Recently, these tests were about to break
glance as they mocked internal methods. Those mocks were
removed in commit eab1567d48a18fa968c7b66c3641dd037da1f84e.

The tests are added back to glance_store in
change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/273786.

Depends-On: I688629d37e9146aef33fbc9bb6fd8780521e06ab
Change-Id: Ic67826a4d02cb30cc429a3d4abc46d6ca96f31ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/89/273789/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: class TestStoreAddToBackend(utils.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestStoreAddToBackend, self).setUp() self.image_id = "animage" self.data = "dataandstuff" self.size = len(self.data) self.location = "file:///ab/cde/fgh" self.checksum = "md5" def _bad_metadata(self, in_metadata): mstore = mock.Mock() mstore.add.return_value = (self.location, self.size, self.checksum, in_metadata) mstore.__str__ = lambda self: "hello" mstore.__unicode__ = lambda self: "hello" self.assertRaises(glance_store.BackendException, glance_store.store_add_to_backend, self.image_id, self.data, self.size, mstore) def _good_metadata(self, in_metadata): mstore = mock.Mock() mstore.add.return_value = (self.location, self.size, self.checksum, in_metadata) (location, size, checksum, metadata) = glance_store.store_add_to_backend(self.image_id, self.data, self.size, mstore) self.assertEqual(self.location, location) self.assertEqual(self.size, size) self.assertEqual(self.checksum, checksum) self.assertEqual(in_metadata, metadata) def test_empty(self): metadata = {} self._good_metadata(metadata) def test_string(self): metadata = {'key': u'somevalue'} self._good_metadata(metadata) def test_list(self): m = {'key': [u'somevalue', u'2']} self._good_metadata(m) def test_unicode_dict(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue'} m = {'topkey': inner} self._good_metadata(m) def test_unicode_dict_list(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue'} m = {'topkey': inner, 'list': [u'somevalue', u'2'], 'u': u'2'} self._good_metadata(m) def test_nested_dict(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue'} inner = {'newkey': inner} inner = {'anotherkey': inner} m = {'topkey': inner} self._good_metadata(m) def test_bad_top_level_nonunicode(self): metadata = {'key': b'a string'} self._bad_metadata(metadata) def test_bad_nonunicode_dict_list(self): inner = {'key1': u'somevalue', 'key2': u'somevalue', 'k3': [1, object()]} m = {'topkey': inner, 'list': [u'somevalue', u'2'], 'u': u'2'} self._bad_metadata(m) def test_bad_metadata_not_dict(self): self._bad_metadata([])

subject: Replication V2 for Pure Storage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-19 23:10:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e090b9fc7df6bfedac61f8a5eec44f744209feab', 'message': 'WIP - Replication V2 for Pure Storage

Implementing replication V2 for Pure Storage driver.

Implements: bp pure-v2-replication
Change-Id: I69e567143b65e92f89969ff5036c4f242c17a1dd
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-19 23:16:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/22f2d918ec7f6720cf4f94abdfb2531c78974f19', 'message': 'WIP - Replication V2 for Pure Storage

Implementing replication V2 for Pure Storage driver.

Implements: bp pure-v2-replication
Change-Id: I69e567143b65e92f89969ff5036c4f242c17a1dd
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-21 22:54:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7b1cca2fd484d65018874598878ad89ed331aa66', 'message': 'WIP - Replication V2 for Pure Storage

This implementation utilizes Pure Storage Protection Groups to
replicate volumes natively between Pure Storage backends.

Replication schedules can be set via config file options.
Replication targets are also set via config file options.

For example,
[puredriver-1]
volume_backend_name = puredriver-1
...
unmanaged_replication_devices={san_ip=<ip-address> api_token=<token>}
pure_replica_pgroup_name_default = cinder-replication-group
pure_replica_interval_default = 900
pure_replica_retention_short_term_default = 14400
pure_replica_retention_long_term_per_day_default = 3
pure_replica_retention_long_term_default = 7

The above settings will cause a protection group to be created between
the two flash arrays. It will replicate any volumes placed in it with
settings that cause a volume to replicated every 15 mins (900s).  All
snapshots will be kept for 4 hours (14400s).  Then 3 snapshots per day
will be kept for 7 days.

Implements: bp pure-v2-replication
Change-Id: I69e567143b65e92f89969ff5036c4f242c17a1dd
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-08-24 00:21:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7d7fa82ea0611ffc0e6985c0d418167f93f26455', 'message': 'Replication V2 for Pure Storage

commit_message:
Replication V2 for Pure Storage

This implementation utilizes Pure Storage Protection Groups to
replicate volumes natively between Pure Storage backends.

Replication schedules can be set via config file options.
Replication targets are also set via config file options.

For example,
[puredriver-1]
volume_backend_name = puredriver-1
...
replication_device = target_device_id:<unique_array_id>,
                     managed_backend_name:puredriver-2,
                     san_ip:<ip_address>,
                     api_token:<authentication_token>
pure_replica_interval_default = 900
pure_replica_retention_short_term_default = 14400
pure_replica_retention_long_term_per_day_default = 3
pure_replica_retention_long_term_default = 7

replication_device describes the target array for replication. This can
be either another managed cinder backend or one not managed by cinder.

The above settings will cause a protection group to be created between
the two flash arrays. It will replicate any volumes placed in it with
settings that cause a volume to be replicated every 15 mins (900s).  All
snapshots will be kept for 4 hours (14400s).  Then 3 snapshots per day
will be kept for 7 days.

Note that replication-failover is supported from primary to any of
multiple secondary arrays, but subsequent replication-failover is
only supported back to the original primary.

DocImpact
Implements: bp pure-v2-replication
Change-Id: I69e567143b65e92f89969ff5036c4f242c17a1dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/25/214825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_service import loopingcallfrom cinder import contextfrom cinder.volume import volume_types # Temp option for Replication, will be moved to common code cfg.StrOpt("replica_san_ip", default=None, help="Address of replication target array"), # Temp option for Replication, will be moved to common code cfg.StrOpt("pure_replica_api_token", default=None, help="REST API token for replication target array"), cfg.StrOpt("pure_replica_pgroup_name", default="cinder-repl-pg", help="Name of protection group that is replicated"), cfg.IntOpt("pure_replica_interval", default=900, help="Snapshot replication interval in seconds"), cfg.IntOpt("pure_replica_retention_short_term", default=14400, help="Retain all snapshots on target for this " "time (in seconds)"), cfg.IntOpt("pure_replica_retention_long_term_per_day", default=3, help="Retain how many snapshots for each day"), cfg.IntOpt("pure_replica_retention_long_term", default=7, help="Retain pure_replication_retention_long_term_per_day" " snapshots per day on target for this time (in days)"),ERR_MSG_ALREADY_EXISTS = "already exists" ERR_MSG_COULD_NOT_BE_FOUND = "could not be found" _retry_counter = {} self._replication_target_array = None self._replication_pg_name = None self._replication_target_api_token = None self._replication_interval = None self._replication_retention_short_term = None self._replication_retention_long_term = None self._replication_retention_long_term_per_day = None self._is_replication_enabled = False array_info = self._array.get() self._array.array_name = array_info["array_name"] self._array.array_id = array_info["id"] # Get replication target array info and create pgroup if needed if self.configuration.replica_san_ip is not None: self._replication_target_array = purestorage.FlashArray( target=self.configuration.replica_san_ip, api_token=self.configuration.pure_replica_api_token) target_array_info = self._replication_target_array.get() self._replication_target_array.array_name = ( target_array_info["array_name"]) self._replication_target_array.array_id = ( target_array_info["id"]) self._replication_pg_name = ( self.configuration.pure_replica_pgroup_name) self._replication_interval = ( self.configuration.pure_replica_interval) self._replication_retention_short_term = ( self.configuration.pure_replica_retention_short_term) self._replication_retention_long_term = ( self.configuration.pure_replica_retention_long_term) self._replication_retention_long_term_per_day = ( self.configuration.pure_replica_retention_long_term_per_day) self._setup_replicated_pgroup( self._array, self._replication_target_array) self._setup_replicated_pgroup( self._replication_target_array, self._array) self._is_replication_enabled = True if self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume): self._array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, addvollist=[self._get_vol_name(volume)]) self._array.create_pgroup_snapshot(self._replication_pg_name, replicate_now=True, apply_retention=True) model_update = {'replication_status': 'active', 'provider_location': self._array.array_id} return model_update # Check which backend the snapshot is on. In case of failover and # snapshot on failed over volume the snapshot may be on the # secondary array. current_array = self._get_current_array(snapshot) current_array.copy_volume(snap_name, vol_name) self._extend_if_needed(current_array, vol_name, snapshot["volume_size"], # TODO(dwilson): figure out if we need to mirror consisgroup on # target array if failover has occurred. model_update = {"provider_location": current_array.array_id} if self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume): current_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, addvollist=[self._get_vol_name(volume)]) current_array.create_pgroup_snapshot(self._replication_pg_name, replicate_now=True, apply_retention=True) model_update['replication_status'] = 'active' return model_update # Check which backend the source volume is on. In case of failover # the source volume may be on the secondary array. current_array = self._get_current_array(src_vref) current_array.copy_volume(src_name, vol_name) self._extend_if_needed(current_array, vol_name, src_vref["size"], volume["size"]) # TODO(dwilson): figure out if we need to mirror consisgroup on # target array if failover has occurred. model_update = {"provider_location": current_array.array_id} if self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume): current_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, addvollist=[self._get_vol_name(volume)]) current_array.create_pgroup_snapshot(self._replication_pg_name, replicate_now=True, apply_retention=True) model_update['replication_status'] = 'active' return model_update def _extend_if_needed(self, array, vol_name, src_size, vol_size): array.extend_volume(vol_name, vol_size) current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) current_array.list_volume_private_connections(vol_name) self._disconnect_host(current_array, host_name, vol_name) current_array.destroy_volume(vol_name) # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication. current_array = self._get_current_array(snapshot) current_array.create_snapshot(vol_name, suffix=snap_suff) # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication. current_array = self._get_current_array(snapshot) current_array.destroy_volume(snap_name) def _get_host(self, array, connector): def _disconnect(self, array, volume, connector, **kwargs): host = self._get_host(array, connector) result = self._disconnect_host(array, host_name, vol_name) # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication. current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) self._disconnect(current_array, volume, connector, **kwargs) def _disconnect_host(self, array, host_name, vol_name): array.disconnect_host(host_name, vol_name) not array.list_host_connections(host_name, private=True)): array.delete_host(host_name) "replication": self._is_replication_enabled, # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) current_array.extend_volume(vol_name, new_size) # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication. current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) current_array.rename_volume(vol_name, unmanaged_vol_name) @staticmethod def _connect_host_to_vol(array, host_name, vol_name): connection = array.connect_host(host_name, vol_name) connected_hosts = ( array.list_volume_private_connections(vol_name)) # Replication v2 @log_debug_trace def replication_enable(self, context, volume, asynch, replica_count): # Enable replication on the given volume # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) if (replica_count == 1 and asynch and self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume)): current_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, addvollist=[self._get_vol_name(volume)]) current_array.create_pgroup_snapshot(self._replication_pg_name, replicate_now=True, apply_retention=True) model_update = {'replication_status': 'active', 'provider_location': current_array.array_id} return model_update @log_debug_trace def replication_disable(self, context, volume): # Disable replication on the given volume # Get current array in case we have failed over via replication current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) if self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume): try: current_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, remvollist=( [self._get_vol_name(volume)])) except purestorage.PureHTTPError as err: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctxt: ctxt.reraise = False if (err.code == 400 and ERR_MSG_COULD_NOT_BE_FOUND in err.text): # Replication is already disabled return {'replication_status': 'disabled'} else: LOG.debug("Disable replication on volume failed with " "message: %s", err.text) return {'replication_status': 'disable_failed'} @log_debug_trace def replication_failover(self, context, volume, secondary): # failover the volume to the secondary if not volume["replication_status"] == "active": raise exception.PureDriverException( reason="Unable to promote replica when replication is not " "active. Current replication status: %s" % volume["replication_status"]) return self.create_replica_test_volume(volume, secondary) @log_debug_trace def get_replication_targets(self, context): # return all connected arrays that are active data = [{"remote_targets": [{"san_ip": self.configuration.san_ip, "san_token": self.configuration.pure_api_token, "status": self._is_replication_enabled}]}, {"cinder_hosts": [self._array.array_name]}, ] return data def _get_current_array(self, volume): current_array, _ = self._get_arrays(volume) return current_array def _get_secondary(self, volume): _, secondary = self._get_arrays(volume) return secondary def _get_arrays(self, volume): """Returns the current and secondary array for a volume or snapshot :param volume: dictionary describing the volume or snapshot :return: the (current_array, secondary) array for the volume """ current_array = volume.get("provider_location", None) # Default to configured current array, including case when # provider_location is misconfigured primary_array = self._array.array_id secondary_array = self._replication_target_array.array_id if (current_array and self._replication_target_array.array_id and self._replication_target_array.id == current_array): primary_array = self._replication_target_array secondary_array = self._array return primary_array, secondary_array @log_debug_trace def create_replica_test_volume(self, volume, secondary): """Creates a new volume from the replica.""" vol_name = self._get_vol_name(volume) # Get the latest replicated snapshot for src_name volume # Look for "source": "<source_array>:<vol_name>" in snapshot attributes current_array, secondary_array = self._get_arrays(volume) vol_source_name_to_find = "%s:%s" % (current_array.array_name, vol_name) volume_snap = self._get_latest_replicated_vol_snap( secondary, current_array.array_name, self._replication_protection_group, vol_name) if not volume_snap: raise exception.PureDriverException( reason="Unable to find volume snapshot for %s" % vol_source_name_to_find) # Create volume from snapshot secondary_array.copy_volume(volume_snap["name"], vol_name, overwrite=True) # New volume inherits replicated type, but is not actively replicating model_update = {"provider_location": secondary_array.array_id, "replication_status": "inactive"} return model_update def _does_pgroup_exist(self, array, pgroup_name): """Return True/False""" try: array.get_pgroup(pgroup_name) return True except purestorage.PureHTTPError as err: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctxt: if err.code == 400 and "does not exist" in err.text: ctxt.reraise = False return False # Any unexpected exception to be handled by caller def _retry_a_function_until_success(self, function, test_function, timeout_exception, max_retries): """Generic method to use in retry-wait pattern with loopingCall :param function: The function to try :param test_function: the test to apply on result of function :param timeout_exception: exception to raise if we exceed max_retries :param max_retries: how many times to retry :return: nothing """ if function not in self._retry_counter.keys(): self._retry_counter[function] = 0 # first call for this function self._retry_counter[function] += 1 if self._retry_counter[function] > max_retries: raise timeout_exception result = function() test_result = test_function(result) if test_result: raise loopingcall.LoopingCallDone() @log_debug_trace def _wait_until_target_group_setting_propagates( self, target_array, pgroup_name_on_target, max_retries, retry_interval): timer = loopingcall.FixedIntervalLoopingCall( self._retry_a_function_until_success, # function to retry lambda: self._does_pgroup_exist( target_array, pgroup_name_on_target), # test_function lambda x: x, # timeout_exception exception.PureDriverException( reason=_("timeout waiting for PG info %s to propagate to " "target array") % pgroup_name_on_target), # maximum no of retries max_retries) timer.start(retry_interval, 0).wait() @log_debug_trace def _wait_until_source_array_allowed(self, source_array, pgroup_name, max_retries, retry_interval): timer = loopingcall.FixedIntervalLoopingCall( self._retry_a_function_until_success, # function to retry lambda: source_array.get_pgroup(pgroup_name), # test_function lambda x: x["targets"][0]["allowed"], # timeout_exception exception.PureDriverException( reason=_("timeout waiting for source array %s acknowledge " "replication allowed status") % source_array.array_name), # Maximum no of retries max_retries) timer.start(retry_interval, 0).wait() def _get_pgroup_name_on_target(self, source_array_name, pgroup_name): return "%s:%s" % (source_array_name, pgroup_name) @log_debug_trace def _setup_replicated_pgroup(self, source_array, target_array): retry_interval = 5 # 5 seconds max_retries = 12 # 12 * 5 = 60 seconds self._create_protection_group_if_not_exist( source_array, self._replication_pg_name) """Apply retention policies to a protection group These retention policies will be applied on the replicated snapshots on the target array""" retention_policy = self._generate_replication_retention() source_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, **retention_policy) """Configure replication propagation frequency on a protection group replicate_interval maps to replicate_frequency in Purity REST API""" source_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, replicate_frequency=self._replication_interval) try: # Configure PG to replicate to target_array source_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, addtargetlist=[target_array.array_name]) except purestorage.PureHTTPError as err: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctxt: if err.code == 400 and \ "Protection group already includes target" in err.text: ctxt.reraise = False LOG.info(_LI("skipping add target %(target_array)s to " "PG %(pgname)s since it's already added"), {"target_array": target_array.array_name, "pgname": self._replication_pg_name}) # Wait until "Target Group" setting propagates to target_array pgroup_name_on_target = self._get_pgroup_name_on_target( source_array.array_name, self._replication_pg_name) self._wait_until_target_group_setting_propagates( target_array, pgroup_name_on_target, max_retries, retry_interval) try: # Configure the target_array to allow replication from the # PG on source_array target_array.set_pgroup(pgroup_name_on_target, allowed=True) except purestorage.PureHTTPError as err: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctxt: if err.code == 400 and \ "Protection group is already allowed on this " \ "target" in err.text: ctxt.reraise = False LOG.info(_LI("skipping allow pgroup %(pgname)s on " "target array %(target_array)s since it's " "already allowed"), {"pgname": self._replication_pg_name, "target_array": target_array.array_name}) # Wait until source array acknowledges previous operation self._wait_until_source_array_allowed( source_array, self._replication_pg_name, max_retries, retry_interval) # Start replication on the PG source_array.set_pgroup(self._replication_pg_name, replicate_enabled=True) def _generate_replication_retention(self): """Generates replication retention settings in Purity compatible format An example of the settings: target_all_for = 14400 (i.e. 4 hours) target_per_day = 6 target_days = 4 The settings above configure the target array to retain 4 hours of the most recent snapshots. After the most recent 4 hours, the target will choose 4 snapshots per day from the previous 6 days for retention :return: a dictionary representing replication retention settings """ LOG.debug("Enter PureISCSIDriver._generate_replication_retention.") replication_retention = dict( target_all_for=self._replication_retention_short_term, target_per_day=self._replication_retention_long_term_per_day, target_days=self._replication_retention_long_term ) LOG.debug("Leave PureISCSIDriver._generate_replication_retention.") return replication_retention @log_debug_trace def _get_latest_replicated_vol_snap(self, array, source_array_name, pgroup_name, vol_name): # Get all protection group snapshots snap_name = "%s:%s" % (source_array_name, pgroup_name) pg_snaps = array.get_pgroup(snap_name, snap=True, transfer=True) # Only use snapshots that are replicated completely pg_snaps_filtered = [s for s in pg_snaps if s["progress"] == 1] # Go through the protection group snapshots, latest first .... # stop when we find required volume snapshot pg_snaps_filtered.sort(key=lambda x: x["created"], reverse=True) volume_snap = None vol_snap_source_to_find = "%s:%s" % (source_array_name, vol_name) LOG.debug("looking for volume %s", vol_snap_source_to_find) for pg_snap in pg_snaps: LOG.debug("looking inside snap %s", pg_snap["name"]) # Get volume snapshots inside the replicated PG snapshot volume_snaps = array._request("GET", "volume/%s?snap=true&pgroup=true" % pg_snap["name"]) for snap in volume_snaps: if snap["source"] == vol_snap_source_to_find: volume_snap = snap if volume_snap: # Found the volume snapshot we needed break return volume_snap @log_debug_trace def _create_protection_group_if_not_exist(self, source_array, pgname): try: source_array.create_pgroup(pgname) except purestorage.PureHTTPError as err: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctxt: if err.code == 400 and ERR_MSG_ALREADY_EXISTS in err.text: # Happens if the PG already exists ctxt.reraise = False LOG.warning(_LW("Skipping creation of PG %s since it " "already exists"), pgname) # We assume PG has already been setup with correct # replication settings. return if err.code == 400 \ and ERR_MSG_PENDING_ERADICATION in err.text: ctxt.reraise = False LOG.warning(_LW("PG %s is deleted but not eradicated " "- will recreate"), pgname) source_array.eradicate_pgroup(pgname) source_array.create_pgroup(pgname) def _is_volume_replicated_type(volume): ctxt = context.get_admin_context() volume_type = volume_types.get_volume_type(ctxt, volume["volume_type_id"]) replication_flag = False specs = volume_type.get("extra_specs") if specs and "capabilities:replication" in specs: replication_capability = specs["capabilities:replication"] # Do not validate settings, ignore invalid replication_flag = (replication_capability == "<is> True") return replication_flag def _get_host(self, array, connector): hosts = array.list_hosts() current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) host = self._get_host(current_array, connector) current_array.create_host(host_name, iqnlist=[iqn]) current_array.set_host(host_name, host_user=chap_username, host_password=chap_password) connection = self._connect_host_to_vol(current_array, host_name, vol_name) def _get_host(self, array, connector): hosts = array.list_hosts() @staticmethod def _get_array_wwns(array): ports = array.list_ports() current_array = self._get_current_array(volume) target_wwns = self._get_array_wwns(current_array) def _connect(self, array, volume, connector): host = self._get_host(array, connector) array.create_host(host_name, wwnlist=wwns) return self._connect_host_to_vol(array, host_name, vol_name)

commit_message:
Do not use "file" builtin, but "open" instead

In Python 2 there is a file type builtin, but this is not the case for
Python 3. Replace it with "open" where possible, and replace with a
StringIO when we are mocking an output file.

Partial-Bug: #1456955
Change-Id: Ifcfed3865c41f1e772fda3717736aead713b37d6

subject: Sync requirements from global requirements
revisions:

spec repo has requirement which are not in sync with g-r.

Incompatible dependency issue can occur due to old versions in
requirements.txt

One example is "Detected a distutils installed project" issue is hitting
for argparse which can be fixed by Ib7e74912b36c1b5ccb514e31fac35efeff57378d
-http://logs.openstack.org/34/269934/1/check/gate-qa-specs-docs/fc7a540/console.html

But to avoid such issue in future its better to sync all requirements with g-r.

This will be needed if check requirements job is going to be added for qa-specs.
Related-Bug: #1536535

commit_message:
Sync requirements from global requirements

spec repo has requirement which are not in sync with g-r.

Incompatible dependency issue can occur due to old versions in
requirements.txt

One example is "Detected a distutils installed project" issue is hitting
for argparse which can be fixed by Ib7e74912b36c1b5ccb514e31fac35efeff57378d
-http://logs.openstack.org/34/269934/1/check/gate-qa-specs-docs/fc7a540/console.html

But to avoid such issue in future its better to sync all requirements with g-r.

This will be needed if check requirements job is going to be added for qa-specs.
Related-Bug: #1536535

Change-Id: Ic85e33c56c94b86ded656ca8405fbb30caeee824

commit_message:
Remove DDT spec

DDT won't be introduced since it adds additional complexity (generated test
names) which should be avoided in the gate.

For more details see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/223953/
Change-Id: Iaee81dfcef308d2a087dc42733250999b6cb52be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qa-specs refs/changes/49/271149/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Data driven testing for Tempest =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/tempest-ddt Add support for data driven testing within Tempest. Problem Description =================== Currently we see tests with for-loop that iterate through different data set. This can be problematic for debugging and in general for test separation (See [1] for some samples). Proposed Change =============== Using the ddt framework [2] to extract the data out of the tests. DDT will dynamically create tests out of the given data set. The DDT framework is already heavily used by unit tests within the projects. Example ------- The test before ddt:: icmp_type_codes = [(3, 2), (3, 0), (8, 0), (0, 0), (11, None)] for icmp_type, icmp_code in icmp_type_codes: self._create_verify_security_group_rule(sg_id, direction, self.ethertype, protocol, icmp_type, icmp_code) Instead of iterating through a set of data the corresponding ddt code would look like:: @ddt.data((3, 2), (3, 0), (8, 0), (0, 0), (11, None)) def test_create_security_group_rule_with_icmp_type_code(self, type_codes): self._create_verify_security_group_rule(sg_id, direction, self.ethertype, protocol, type_codes[0], type_codes[1]) Performance ----------- Any generated test will rerun setUp() and tearDown(). Code on class level should work without any change (and no rerun at all). In Tempest the resource setup is usually done within class methods which won't effect the performance. Idempotent_id and refstack -------------------------- Since refstack should handle generated tests under the same id, it should be fine to use the idempotent decorator to uniquely identify the test group. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: Marc Koderer Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: mitaka-3 Work Items ---------- * Implement idempotent_id functionality * Port tests Dependencies ============ None. References ========== 1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/223953/ 2. https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ddt .. _config_tempest.py: https://github.com/redhat-openstack/tempest/blob/master/tools/config_tempest.py

remove python 2.6 trove classifier

remove the trove classifier implying that this project supports 2.6.

commit_message:
Print unparsable file in pkg-map

As you can see in the CI failures for
Ib11b9df84b593ab25232729a570c812f1b4b8774, you can not see what file
is causing the problems when the parser fails.  Add a print, but raise
the error as it contains the cause.

Change-Id: I127ff7d57d2d898969195464c6e774d496e872e6

commit_message:
[Core-Library] Increase format version

Currently we are using a lot of features from yaql 1.0.0
in core-library, but we still have old version of format.
Increasing of it to 1.1 demonstrates that library package
can be used only with Liberty+ versions of Murano

Change-Id: Ic0d0175e857d29d862a80663f6518e108343142d

commit_message:
[Core-Library] Fix the way of getting DNS in describe() method

This patch changes the method of getting dns address.
Previously dns could be an empty list, if user didn't configured
'default_dns' settings in murano.conf. Now it is taken from already
created subnet.

Change-Id: I5c6a831738e8d971a12bd81eff42aebc869c9a2e
Related-Bug: #1536651
(cherry picked from commit 275b2d2583765ded206000ecf963ae093e641290)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/69/275069/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dns: $subnet.dns_nameservers

their super class TestVolume to avoid redundant code.

commit_message:
Introduce a new method to format the output of dicts

Add an assistant method "print_dict()" to format the output of dicts
with two columns. And also, wrap length, column name can be customized
with this method.

Change-Id: Ic4317a2ea60a2327162f35de0c8cb737a7e807d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/61/254561/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import textwrapfrom oslo_utils import encodeutilsimport prettytable def print_dict(dct, dict_field='Field', dict_value='Value', wrap=0): """Print a `dict` as a table of two columns. :param dct: `dict` to print :param dict_field: name of the first column :param wrap: wrapping for the second column :param dict_value: name of the second column """ pt = prettytable.PrettyTable([dict_field, dict_value]) pt.align = 'l' for k, v in sorted(dct.items()): # convert dict to str to check length if isinstance(v, dict): v = six.text_type(v) if wrap > 0: v = textwrap.fill(six.text_type(v), wrap) # if value has a newline, add in multiple rows # e.g. fault with stacktrace if v and isinstance(v, six.string_types) and r'\n' in v: lines = v.strip().split(r'\n') col1 = k for line in lines: pt.add_row([col1, line]) col1 = '' else: pt.add_row([k, v]) if six.PY3: print(encodeutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string()).decode()) else: print(encodeutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string()))

commit_message:
Material: Better Inverse Dropdown Header Color

Right now, Bootswatch's 'paper' sets the color of the
.dropdown-header to be a light gray regardless of whether its an
inverse navbar. This is not ideal. It should inherit the same color.

Change-Id: I1b4664073b84a9a76ded4041afe021430d976c0e
Closes-bug: #1540745
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/14/275014/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .dropdown-header { color: $navbar-inverse-link-color; font-weight: bold; }

commit_message:
Add --wrap option for "hypervisor show"

The command "hypervisor show" always outputs quite long lines which
make uncomfortale reading for users, so this patch tries to add a
"--wrap" option to customize the length of lines.
Default is disabled.

Change-Id: I8411f44cd74d57f3cf8dae5abd3e381b54d91a74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/62/254562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [--wrap <integer>] <hypervisor> .. option:: --wrap <integer> Wrap the output to a specified length. Default is 0 to disable.

commit_message:
Fix l2-gateway-connection delete

After creating a gateway and connection, then trying to delete the
connection, we hit the problem at the last call to
delete_ucast_macs_remote in delete_vif_from_gateway.  The call requires
4 parameters, but only 3 are given.

Change-Id: I39337261d17b5031f17def0d1d2dfa43f1920bb3

commit_message:
Don't decide web_framework before config parse

This ensures that the config files passed on the CLI
are parsed before the choice is made based on config options
to launch pecan/homegrown wsgi handler.

Closes-Bug: #1537292
Change-Id: I577befea74d84d611cd198c92c54ae3651e2d921

commit_message:
Try vxlan instead of gre for overlays

It looks like some providers may not allow IP type 47 (GRE) traffic to
pass their networks. See if using vxlan is a useable workaround.

Change-Id: I951e7e1bd98eeaf347e85296c12e027e225c2c97

commit_message:
add a job to send automated announcements of releases

Define a new job {name}-announce-release to send announcements of new
releases and associate it with the "release" queue to be run after the
release is completed and uploaded to PyPI (for libraries) or the tarball
server (for server projects). We don't want pre-releases (alphas, betas,
and release candidates) to have announcements generated automatically.

The job uses a script in the openstack-infra/release-tools repository to
actually generate and send the email. This is part of the same set of
tools we've been using for manual release announcements.

Spec: release-automation
Story: 2000421
Change-Id: I8106f8449d6c41da6b799aee484e81ffebb498bf
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Jeremy Stanley <fungi@yuggoth.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/67/272767/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Announce the release of a new package. - job-template: name: '{name}-announce-release' node: bare-trusty builders: - print-template-name: template-name: "{template-name}" - revoke-sudo - gerrit-git-prep - shell: | #!/bin/bash # Save the version that was just tagged by parsing # ref/tags/VALUE to get VALUE. VERSION=$(echo $ZUUL_REF | cut -f2 -d/) # Check out the release-tools, ignoring any other ZUUL # variables that might confuse the cloner and cause it to # try to check out anything like the commit that was just # tagged or to look for a branch (we always want the master # version of the tools). for v in $(env | grep '^ZUUL_' | cut -f1 -d=); do unset $v done TOOLS_TMP=$(mktemp -d) /usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner \ --cache-dir /opt/git \ --workspace $TOOLS_TMP \ git://git.openstack.org openstack-infra/release-tools TOOLS_DIR=$TOOLS_TMP/openstack-infra/release-tools # Run the announce script. $TOOLS_DIR/announce.sh $WORKSPACE $VERSION publishers: - console-log - job-group: name: release-announce-jobs jobs: - '{name}-announce-release'

Refactor the current execute and revert functions
to be co-located with the work units that handle
making that work occur.

This makes it easier to identify what work unit

'}]
commit_message:
Create and use individual work units

Refactor the current execute and revert functions
to be co-located with the work units that handle
making that work occur.

This makes it easier to identify what work unit
is scheduled (or to be scheduled) and makes it easier
to identify what code will be finally called to execute
that work unit.

Change-Id: I76c23497fe9a851e22d53c004e51b57d8eca9737

added_lines: def manage_snapshot(self, share_id, name=None, description=None, version=LATEST_MICROVERSION, url=None): import pdb; pdb.set_trace() post_body = { "snapshot": { "share_id": share_id, "name": name, "description": description, } } if url is None: url = 'snapshots/manage' body = json.dumps(post_body) resp, body = self.post(url, body, version=version) self.expected_success(200, resp.status) return self._parse_resp(body) def unmanage_snapshot(self, snapshot_id, version=LATEST_MICROVERSION, url=None, action_name=None, body=None): if url is None: url = 'snapshots' if action_name is None: action_name = 'action' if body is None: body = json.dumps({'unmanage': {}}) resp, body = self.post( "%(url)s/%(snapshot_id)s/%(action_name)s" % { 'url': url, 'snapshot_id': snapshot_id, 'action_name': action_name}, body, version=version) self.expected_success(202, resp.status) return body ###############

commit_message:
Migrate agnostic policy engine to dse2

Original tests still work.

To run the new tests:
python3 -m "nose" congress/tests2/dse2/test_dse2.py

Implements: blueprint dist-integrate-new-dse
Change-Id: If384644f705d5904ee3093c7244b55001f3bbc54

added_lines: from congress.datalog import compilefrom congress.policy_engines.agnostic import Dse2Runtime data = FakeDataSource('data') engine = Dse2Runtime('engine') node.register_service(data) node.register_service(engine) engine.create_policy('alpha') engine.create_policy('data') self.insert_rule(engine, 'p(x) :- data:fake_table(x)', 'alpha') data.state = {'fake_table': set([(1,), (2,)])} data.poll() helper.retry_check_db_equal(engine, 'p(x)', 'p(1) p(2)', target='alpha') self.assertFalse(hasattr(engine, "last_msg")) def insert_rule(self, engine, statement, target=None): statement = compile.parse1(statement) if target is None: e = compile.Event(statement) else: e = compile.Event(statement, target=target) engine.process_policy_update([e])
deleted_lines: pub = FakeDataSource('pub') sub = FakeDataSource('sub') node.register_service(pub) node.register_service(sub) sub.subscribe('pub', 'fake_table') pub.state = {'fake_table': set([(1, 2)])} pub.poll() helper.retry_check_function_return_value( lambda: sub.last_msg['data'], set(pub.state['fake_table'])) self.assertFalse(hasattr(pub, "last_msg"))

subject: Change Metadefs OS::Nova::Instance to OS::Nova::Server
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-25 21:05:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/f69b2663709d6449be0545d863dcf86b5fd403ab', 'message': 'Change Metadefs OS::Nova::Instance to OS::Nova::Server

The metadata definitions in etc/metadefs allow each namespace to be associated
with a resource type in OpenStack. Now that Horizon is supporting adding
metadata to instances (just got in during the mitaka cycle - so unrealeased),
I realized that we used OS::Nova::Instance instead of OS::Nova::Server in
Glance. This doesn’t align with Heat [0] or Searchlight [1].

There are a couple of metadef files that have OS::Nova::Instance that need to
change to OS::Nova::Server. I see also that OS::Nova:Instance is in one of
the db scripts. That script simply adds some initial "resource types" to the
database. [3]. It should be noted that there is no hard dependency on that
resource type to be in the DB script. You can add new resource types at any
time via API or JSON files and they are automatically added.

I'm not sure if the change to the db script needs to be done in a different
patch or not, but that can easily be accommodated.

See bug for additional links.

Change-Id: I196ce1d9a62a61027ccd444b17a30b2c018d9c84
Closes-Bug: 1537903

commit_message:
Change Metadefs OS::Nova::Instance to OS::Nova::Server

The metadata definitions in etc/metadefs allow each namespace to be associated
with a resource type in OpenStack. Now that Horizon is supporting adding
metadata to instances (just got in during the mitaka cycle - so unrealeased),
I realized that we used OS::Nova::Instance instead of OS::Nova::Server in
Glance. This doesn’t align with Heat [0] or Searchlight [1].

There are a couple of metadef files that have OS::Nova::Instance that need to
change to OS::Nova::Server. I see also that OS::Nova:Instance is in one of
the db scripts. That script simply adds some initial "resource types" to the
database. [3]. It should be noted that there is no hard dependency on that
resource type to be in the DB script. You can add new resource types at any
time via API or JSON files and they are automatically added.

I'm not sure if the change to the db script needs to be done in a different
patch or not, but that can easily be accommodated.

See bug for additional links.

Change-Id: I196ce1d9a62a61027ccd444b17a30b2c018d9c84
Closes-Bug: 1537903

commit_message:
tests: adding fake libosinfo module

Adding a fake libosinfo module in order to avoid mocking it and
perform tests against a fake library.

Partially implements blueprint libvirt-hardware-policy-from-libosinfo

Change-Id: Ia13123ffe46b9c791630d967fd5f4dc1ade0734b

added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Red Hat, Inc # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. def match_item(obj, fltr): key, val = fltr._filter.items()[0] if key == 'class': key = '_class' elif key == 'short-id': key = 'short_id' return getattr(obj, key, None) == val class Loader(object): def process_default_path(self): pass def get_db(self): return Db() class Db(object): def __init__(self): # Generate test devices self.devs = [] self.oslist = None net = Device() net._class = 'net' net.name = 'virtio-net' self.devs.append(net) net = Device() net._class = 'block' net.name = 'virtio-block' self.devs.append(net) devlist = DeviceList() devlist.devices = self.devs fedora = Os() fedora.name = 'Fedora 22' fedora.id = 'http://fedoraproject.org/fedora/22' fedora.short_id = 'fedora22' fedora.dev_list = devlist self.oslist = OsList() self.oslist.os_list = [fedora] def get_os_list(self): return self.oslist class Filter(object): def __init__(self): self._filter = {} @classmethod def new(cls): return cls() def add_constraint(self, flt_key, val): self._filter[flt_key] = val class OsList(object): def __init__(self): self.os_list = [] def new_filtered(self, fltr): new_list = OsList() new_list.os_list = [os for os in self.os_list if match_item(os, fltr)] return new_list def get_length(self): return len(self.os_list) def get_nth(self, index): return self.os_list[index] class Os(object): def __init__(self): self.name = None self.short_id = None self.id = None self.dev_list = None def get_all_devices(self, fltr): new_list = DeviceList() new_list.devices = [dev for dev in self.dev_list.devices if match_item(dev, fltr)] return new_list def get_name(self): self.name class DeviceList(object): def __init__(self): self.devices = [] def get_length(self): return len(self.devices) def get_nth(self, index): return self.devices[index] class Device(object): def __init__(self): self.name = None self._class = None def get_name(self): return self.name

commit_message:
Stop using mox (scheduler)

As part of the ongoing effort to stop using mox, port the scheduler unit
tests to use mock.

Limit the scope of this patch to the modules in:
    nova/tests/unit/scheduler/

Part of bp:remove-mox

Change-Id: I83dd8db4897e1700b2c4d3dde6b782a7ad2a17c7

commit_message:
Prevent user to remove last location of the image

If the last location of the image is removed, image transitions back to queued.
This allows user to upload new data into the existing image record. By
preventing removal of the last location we prevent the image transition back to
queued.

This change also prevents doing the same operation via replacing the locations
with empty list.

SecurityImpact
DocImpact
APIImpact

Conflicts:
	glance/tests/unit/v2/test_images_resource.py

Change-Id: Ieb03aaba887492819f9c58aa67f7acfcea81720e
Closes-Bug: #1525915
(cherry picked from commit e9e45baa9aaf58e69964419b6b4fb2048d115a0c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/36/275736/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- security: - Fixing bug 1525915; image might be transitioning from active to queued by regular user by removing last location of image (or replacing locations with empty list). This allows user to re-upload data to the image breaking Glance's promise of image data immutability. From now on, last location cannot be removed and locations cannot be replaced with empty list.

commit_message:
Do not assign admin to service users

As pointed out by Brant Knudson in change [1], the sample policy file
allows the service user to validate tokens [2], so service users don't
need 'admin' role, they only need 'service'.

This patch adds the 'service' role creation to our tools/sample_data.sh
and updates service roles to it rather than 'admin'.

[1] Iebc4f6b005e0466fe60691d964c7dea0e0eee947
[2] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/etc/policy.json#n94

Change-Id: I3336514f7a2e1e749908d92b693d765c3ed48f51

commit_message:
Create neutron service in sample_data.sh

With the addition of Neutron to the sample_data.sh script, all services
required by the compute starter kit tag [1] are created (plus swift and ec2
compatible credentials)

[1] http://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/compute_starter_kit.html

Change-Id: Iebc4f6b005e0466fe60691d964c7dea0e0eee947

commit_message:
Add schema for OAuth1 consumer API

Add schema validation on create/update of OAuth1 consumer.

This patch also remove the unnecessary code after schema
validation enforcement.

- Remove the check of `secret` in request body for update
consumer API. It is covered by this schema definition.
 'not': {
     'required': ['secret']
 }

- Remove the check of `description` to consistent with other
entities, such as `user`, `group`. It is covered by the following
schema definition.
 'description': validation.nullable(parameter_types.description)

Partially implements: bp schema-validation-extent

Change-Id: I4d7e6188e8120aa4bcb4a27a22a34d7b395d5f49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/91/266791/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.common import validationfrom keystone.oauth1 import schema @validation.validated(schema.consumer_create, 'consumer') @validation.validated(schema.consumer_update, 'consumer')
deleted_lines: self._validate_consumer_ref(ref) def _validate_consumer_ref(self, consumer): if 'secret' in consumer: msg = _('Cannot change consumer secret') raise exception.ValidationError(message=msg)

commit_message:
Don't load deleted instances

When the HostManager starts up, it loads the instance information for
all of the compute nodes. The call it uses, though, includes the records
for deleted instances, which are not needed, and which can cause
performance issues for large deployments. This patch adds a filter on
deleted records.

Closes-bug: 1524421

Change-Id: I404b6baa5504316f447d9c504132183198ff689e
(cherry picked from commit 3d6fac8dea940b62e88f239c5615acc500b74f05)

commit_message:
Router: Add --route and --clear-routes options to "router set" command

--route option will enable users to set routes to the router.
--clear-routes option will help users to clear the routes associated
with the router.

Change-Id: I1af8a25bb89aa58c3e0e45ae26ee6c7daab3c656
Implements: blueprint neutron-client

subject: Allow IPv6 addresses/hostnames in StatsD target
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-21 19:25:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5352f5956712b0ce3e615b9c4e54024fb57274e9', 'message': 'Allow IPv6 addresses/hostnames in StatsD target

The log_statsd_host value can now be an IPv6 address or a hostname which
only resolves to an IPv6 address.  In both cases, the new behavior is to
use an AF_INET6 socket on which .sendto() is called with the
originally-configured hostname (or IP).  This means the Swift process is
not caching a DNS resolution for the lifetime of the process (a good
thing).

If a hostname resolves to both an IPv6 or IPv4 address, an AF_INET
socket is used (i.e. only the IPv4 address will receive the UDP packet).

The old behavior is preserved: any invalid IP address literals and
failures in DNS resolution or actual StatsD packet sending do not halt
the process or bubble up; they are caught, logged, and otherwise ignored.

Change-Id: Ibddddcf140e2e69b08edf3feed3e9a5fa17307cf

commit_message:
Allow IPv6 addresses/hostnames in StatsD target

The log_statsd_host value can now be an IPv6 address or a hostname
which only resolves to an IPv6 address.  In both cases, the new
behavior is to use an AF_INET6 socket on which .sendto() is called
with the originally-configured hostname (or IP).  This means the
Swift process is not caching a DNS resolution for the lifetime of
the process (a good thing).

If a hostname resolves to both an IPv6 or IPv4 address, an AF_INET
socket is used (i.e. only the IPv4 address will receive the UDP
packet).

The old behavior is preserved: any invalid IP address literals and
failures in DNS resolution or actual StatsD packet sending do not
halt the process or bubble up; they are caught, logged, and
otherwise ignored.

Change-Id: Ibddddcf140e2e69b08edf3feed3e9a5fa17307cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/91/270991/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for the other settings are given above. The `log_statsd_host` can be a hostname, an IPv4 address, or an IPv6 address (not surrounded with brackets, as this is unnecessary since the port is specified separately). If a hostname resolves to an IPv4 address, an IPv4 socket will be used to send StatsD UDP packets, even if the hostname would also resolve to an IPv6 address.
deleted_lines: for the other settings are given above.

commit_message:
Add KeyValueListAction to custom parser action

Class KeyValueListAction will be used to parse arguments like this:

--routes destination=xxx,nexthop=xxx --route destination=yyy,nexthop=yyy

The result is a list like this:

[{destination:xxx, nexthop:xxx}, {destination:yyy, nexthop:yyy}]

Change-Id: I45cce94d90eb26a63101361323c76e752821a972
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/27/261827/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class KeyValueListAction(argparse.Action): """A custom action to parse arguments as key1=value1,key2=value2 pairs Ensure that ``dest`` is a list. The list will finally contain multiple dicts, with key-value pairs in them. """ def __call__(self, parser, namespace, values, option_string=None): # Make sure we have an empty list rather than None if getattr(namespace, self.dest, None) is None: setattr(namespace, self.dest, []) tmpdict = {} for kv in values.split(','): # Add value if an assignment else remove it if '=' in kv: tmpdict.update([kv.split('=', 1)]) else: return # Append the dict to the dest list getattr(namespace, self.dest, []).append(tmpdict)

commit_message:
Migrate datasource polling to dse2

Datasource still functions on original dse.

To run new tests:
tox -enew_arch

Implements: blueprint dist-integrate-new-dse

commit_message:
Due to removal of a section for additonal vmware config, update links

Because of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/273886 which removed the
additional config info for vmware vcenter v 5, link to liberty version
of that config info (rather than reverting prior patch).

Change-Id: If31deae3a3a12b5a7d2e9a27f0ae3c878fa895c7

commit_message:
Optimize router delete execution

Optimize the execution of router delete in the L3 agent
by not performing operations in the router namespace that
will be removed as the last step of the workflow.
Comparing the slopes of the least squares fit of delete
execution time shows that this optimization decreases that
slope by over half.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/l3/dvr_edge_ha_router.py
	neutron/agent/l3/router_info.py

Change-Id: Ic425ab1f8c3afe882c9deaa72a814ac0d2053f3b
Signed-off-by: Ryan Moats <rmoats@us.ibm.com>
Closes-Bug: 1512450
(cherry picked from commit 526dac467ba869284dd096c7a9e8251fb1bd4e85)

commit_message:
Fix intermittent fail of test_delete_bulk_account

The test asserts calls made in specific order,
but they are made from threads so may be in
different order.

Change-Id: I857ad3b909c3b635927fb1a39682d66d20c6fd59

commit_message:
Adds support to accept IPv6 in VIP Address for LB Pool

In VIP assignment for a LB pool, it now allows users to assign a
IPv6 IP address also.

Change-Id: I8e7f047c410cde5c13c14a18e27ed25c6c767eb5
Closes-bug: #1403034
(cherry picked from commit dbf251e16e9e518a85991c07d030aa8b2070c9fc)

commit_message:
devstack: use password with version discovery

Devstack will move to keystone v3, so support it here.

Change-Id: I2a6eb7ec63ab6d2d7ac5c8e162ef96197137a966
Closes-bug: #1539728

commit_message:
virt/libvirt: Consider live-resize limits when booting an instance.

Retrieve live-resize limits for memory and vcpus from flavor and
set vcpu and maxMemory values in domain xml accordingly.

Change-Id: Ib96edcf228b6234a8bccb2da1acab265de15c32b

commit_message:
[Orchestration API v1] Missing description and response sample
for List API versions

The method GET of "List API versions" does return a response.
However the desc and the response sample are missing from the
API details.

Change-Id: I51107ff6929a0f8857bd017cca262faa379fbd00
Closes-Bug: #1539549

commit_message:
Neutron: Networking API v2.0 (CURRENT) page should contain unique data type

This patch replaces word "xsd:bool" by "xsd:boolean" for Boolean data type
of all parameters tables in Networking API v2.0 page.

Change-Id: I0619fa89412c8d79e3ed2c10aac99120be270ab8
Closes-Bug: #1539515

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-28 09:46:38.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/loadbalancers/tests.py', 'openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/loadbalancers/workflows.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/lbaas_tests.py', 'openstack_dashboard/test/test_data/neutron_data.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/ee73015788aebe44e835650fbd0329789707fba2', 'message': 'Adds support to accept IPv6 in VIP Address for LB Pool

In VIP assignment for a LB pool, it now allows users to assign a
IPv6 IP address also.

Change-Id: I8e7f047c410cde5c13c14a18e27ed25c6c767eb5
Closes-bug: #1403034
(cherry picked from commit dbf251e16e9e518a85991c07d030aa8b2070c9fc)
'}]
commit_message:
Adds support to accept IPv6 in VIP Address for LB Pool

In VIP assignment for a LB pool, it now allows users to assign a
IPv6 IP address also.

Change-Id: I8e7f047c410cde5c13c14a18e27ed25c6c767eb5
Closes-bug: #1403034
(cherry picked from commit dbf251e16e9e518a85991c07d030aa8b2070c9fc)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/19/273419/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-01 02:42:50.000000000', 'files': ['api-ref/src/wadls/networking-api/src/wadl/networks.wadl'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-site/commit/8ec3d8bf0811be5cf96dd094e4eb882eb92ad224', 'message': 'Neutron: Networking API v2.0 (CURRENT) page contains duplicate parameter name

commit_message:
Neutron: Networking API v2.0 (CURRENT) page contains duplicate parameter name

This patch removes duplicate "network", "admin_state_up", "name", "shared"
and "tenant_id" parameters in "request parameters" table.

Change-Id: I655399fb4b62c972fbcbf07f460df7297af0bb97
Closes-Bug: #1539568
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/91/274491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: &admin_state_upRequestParameter; &nameRequestParameter; &sharedRequestParameter; &tenant_idRequestParameter;
deleted_lines: The administrative state of the network, which is up (true) or down (false). The network name. A request body is optional: If you include it, it can specify this optional attribute. Indicates whether this network is shared across all tenants. By default, only administrative users can change this value. Admin-only. The UUID of the tenant that owns the network. This tenant can be different from the tenant that makes the create network request. However, only administrative users can specify a tenant UUID other than their own. You cannot change this value through authorization policies. &networkObject; &admin_state_upRequestParameter; &nameRequestParameter; &sharedRequestParameter; &tenant_idRequestParameter;

subject: Remove python 2.5 workaround
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-31 14:53:09.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/httpclient.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/cc99324694b684019929ae249fbc661f82a7d0f2', 'message': "Remove python 2.5 workaround

keystoneclient doesn't support python 2.5 so remove this workaround
code. Messing with global variables is a mistake anyways.

Change-Id: I1567508cb1931b8c5365cfe6584e5a732c459db0
"}]
commit_message:
Remove python 2.5 workaround

keystoneclient doesn't support python 2.5 so remove this workaround
code. Messing with global variables is a mistake anyways.

Change-Id: I1567508cb1931b8c5365cfe6584e5a732c459db0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/36/274436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: from six.moves.urllib import parse as urlparse# Python 2.5 compat fix if not hasattr(urlparse, 'parse_qsl'): import cgi urlparse.parse_qsl = cgi.parse_qsl

subject: Update keyring requirements
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-31 14:48:58.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/httpclient.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/cc3aea176c2c047a08cbba7644d32cc6af4825b6', 'message': 'Update keyring requirements

As of commit 05c2bcef the minimum keyring version is 5.5.1,
so update the version that httpclient will use.

Change-Id: I877b9d40b8bc4f89754d64d29d82a9e3a3f2dd04
'}]
commit_message:
Update keyring requirements

As of commit 05c2bcef the minimum keyring version is 5.5.1,
so update the version that httpclient will use.

Change-Id: I877b9d40b8bc4f89754d64d29d82a9e3a3f2dd04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/35/274435/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: keyring_min = pkg_resources.parse_version('5.5.1') # This is a list of versions, e.g., pkg_resources.parse_version('3.3') keyring_bad = []

commit_message:
Update Defcore test list function

Update the defcore test list function to support kilo and liberty.

Conflicts:
	playbooks/roles/os_tempest/templates/openstack_tempest_gate.sh.j2

Change-Id: I36e02459248abbbf60ec4aed6f8bcbaa491e2dba
Closes-Bug: #1533800
(cherry picked from commit 93de17e64220369826a5b6806bfe9fabd749ef9f)

commit_message:
Remove outdated pot files

These files are outdated and not needed, translation is done using our
translation server. The current scripts work even when these files do
not exist. Once there are translated files, the files will be imported
automatically again and updated.

This is part of implementing the new infra setup for translations,
see spec
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack-infra/infra-specs/specs/translation_setup.html
for full details.

Change-Id: I43babe535f1784ce56da2dfcfcbdab7e0d5111c5

commit_message:
Add a script for generating CMC requests on Windows

Change-Id: I18192ca90a83a6e5f05fe783961c7de9db9b6d77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/anchor refs/changes/45/269445/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ' Generate the CMC request with a hardcoded CN from the current user context Const ContextUser = 1 const XCN_CERT_X500_NAME_STR = 3 Set fso = CreateObject ("Scripting.FileSystemObject") Set req = CreateObject("X509Enrollment.CX509CertificateRequestCmc") Set xreq = CreateObject("X509Enrollment.CX509CertificateRequestPkcs10") xreq.Initialize ContextUser xreq.Subject = CreateObject( "X509Enrollment.CX500DistinguishedName" ) xreq.Subject.Encode "CN=anchor-test.example.com", XCN_CERT_X500_NAME_STR req.InitializeFromInnerRequest xreq req.Encode outFile="cmc.req" Set objFile = fso.CreateTextFile(outFile,True) objFile.WriteLine "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----" objFile.WriteLine req.RawData objFile.WriteLine "-----END CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----" objFile.Close

commit_message:
Add support for CMC requests

Incoming CMC requests should be stripped of all wrappers, then the internal
pkcs10 request is processed as usual. No verification is done on the SignedData
wrapper, because there's no known certificate to trust.

Response is just the bare certificate for now.

Change-Id: I92c76df775e5f339ac2fae95582097e3afe138af

commit_message:
Make sure no "empty" extensions are created

Skipping an extension could previously result in an empty entry in the
certificate.

Change-Id: Ibf385ab8841bf33d34b99580bdcfa76f235d6d0e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/anchor refs/changes/67/267967/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ext_i = 0 for ext in exts: logger.info("Adding certificate extension: %i %s", ext_i, str(ext)) new_cert.add_extension(ext, ext_i) ext_i += 1
deleted_lines: for i, ext in enumerate(exts): logger.info("Adding certificate extension: %i %s", i, str(ext)) new_cert.add_extension(ext, i)

commit_message:
New asn1 modules for CMC support

Asn1 modules are autogenerated and not covered by pep8

Change-Id: I7a4e9c308001ed3051e68d2a27e454977f6e787b

subject: clean up Nova policy changes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-03 19:55:12.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/astara/commit/bfbb7e5d2238fd69d624a391d4cf9557854d474d', 'message': 'clean up Nova policy changes

Only change Nova policy settings with Nova is installed.  Also make sure
to use configured value of NOVA_CONF instead of hardcoded path.

Change-Id: I8534c2631186b8937faaa6b82f67bae3a5a5fe7f
'}]
commit_message:
clean up Nova policy changes

Only change Nova policy settings with Nova is installed.  Also make sure
to use configured value of NOVA_CONF instead of hardcoded path.

Change-Id: I8534c2631186b8937faaa6b82f67bae3a5a5fe7f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/astara refs/changes/04/275904/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "Updating Nova policy file" sed -i "s/$old_value/$new_value/g" "$NOVA_CONF_DIR/policy.json" if is_service_enabled n-api; then set_neutron_user_permission fi

subject: Added wheel-release job
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-28 13:47:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/a81b4f9e13b24fa01d266bc223a19123903c1c21', 'message': 'Added wheel-release job

This patch adds a wheel-release job on our release slave,
which is triggered after a wheel is built. It runs vos release,
to push the new entries in the filesystem to our AFS masters.

which is triggered after a wheel is built. It runs vos release,

commit_message:
Added wheel-release job

This patch adds a wheel-release job on our release slave,
which is triggered after a wheel is built. It runs vos release,
to push the new entries in the filesystem to our AFS masters.

Change-Id: Ic1e8a6725fc046d8240a9665f6ed1167be53cb49
Depends-on: I81c39d420d8ac70def57949ea0d4c323b8797086

commit_message:
Support listing network availability zones

Update the "os availability zone list" command to support listing
network availability zones along with the currently listed compute
and volume availability zones. This adds the --network option to
the command in order to only list network availability zones. By
default, all availability zones are listed. The --long option
was also updated to include a "Zone Resource" column which is
applicable to network availability zones. Example zone resources
include "network" and "router".

If the Network API does not support listing availability zones
then a warning message will be issued when the --network option
is specified.

This support requires an updated release of the SDK in order
to pull in [1].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-openstacksdk/+bug/1532274

Change-Id: I78811d659b793d9d2111ea54665d5fe7e4887264
Closes-Bug: #1534202

commit_message:
Allow wait_for_delete to work for all clients

Allow the exception and error status
strings to be passed in such that other plugins can
make use of this function.

There is a comment in find_resource:
  The exception to catch here is dependent on which
  client library the manager passed in belongs to.
  Eventually this should be pulled from a common set
  of client exceptions.

Since I think that is a long ways off, this change will
work now and also work when a common exception is defined
and used.

Change-Id: Iab56cd1166028caed4f1e657e0b1ee81af3f48d8

subject: Fix vs_port usage in Red Hat distros
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-02 10:07:49.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/vs_port/ovs_redhat.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-vswitch/commit/f8aba9c28ffc49e2de34452aefb17fa85296ff5d', 'message': 'Fix vs_port usage in Red Hat distros

Commit f39a4ca961ac1353b48c60d2c27aebba8ae1b2da moved constant
creation inside a do block to avoid duplication warnings, but at
the same time renamed them to self::BASE and self::DEFAULT, causing
issues when those variables where used elsewhere (e.g. in
lib/puppetx/redhat/ifcfg.rb).

Renaming those variables back and using ||= for assignment removes
the warning, while at the same time fixes the issues created by the
previous commit.

Change-Id: I3a02710811d91e141d56ab476dd32c3c7cf0ca80
(cherry picked from commit eb1677526ceaa97b98b7b85e23b3a6b95b5eaf2f)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix vs_port usage in Red Hat distros

Commit f39a4ca961ac1353b48c60d2c27aebba8ae1b2da moved constant
creation inside a do block to avoid duplication warnings, but at
the same time renamed them to self::BASE and self::DEFAULT, causing
issues when those variables where used elsewhere (e.g. in
lib/puppetx/redhat/ifcfg.rb).

Renaming those variables back and using ||= for assignment removes
the warning, while at the same time fixes the issues created by the
previous commit.

Change-Id: I3a02710811d91e141d56ab476dd32c3c7cf0ca80
(cherry picked from commit eb1677526ceaa97b98b7b85e23b3a6b95b5eaf2f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-vswitch refs/changes/00/275100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BASE ||= '/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-' DEFAULT ||= {

revisions:

Apache knows .txt files are text/plain by default, but doesn't know
what to make of .log files. Rather than hack encoding overrides into

what to make of .log files. Rather than hack encoding overrides into

commit_message:
Rename .log to .log.txt in run-tox

Apache knows .txt files are text/plain by default, but doesn't know
what to make of .log files. Rather than hack encoding overrides into
our logserver vhost, just rename the log files by tox only
in run-tox.sh before uploading so that they can be served properly.

Change-Id: I03cba279037259fcaa5073d67caf23662b3a59d2
